develop communication skills to advocate for social justice initiatives

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 is a series of writing tasks that you will engage in during class time 4 times throughout the semester:

* The first task, due in Week 2 of semester, is a practice task, so that you will know what to expect for the rest of semester. It is not graded.

* The remaining 3 writing tasks are graded and are worth 20% each, making a total of 60% of your mark. The graded components will be due in class in Weeks 5, 8, and 11. 

The writing exercises will occur in the second half of the workshop. You will be given a maximum of 45 minutes to read through a short case study and respond to a question. Your response will be a maximum of 500 words. The writing task will be based on the work you have done in the modules and the in-class exercises and discussions that have occurred prior to the allocated workshop. 

This assessment will be completed in-class via Inspera. Students will be required to bring their own laptop computer, or borrow a laptop computer from the library

Please see Blackboard for further details about the task and how it will be graded. 

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI): This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
In this assignment, you will create a 3-minute video pitch in response to a scenario, to articulate the importance of responding to a particular area of social inequality. Drawing on concepts learned in the course, and your own research, you will identify a compelling argument for addressing systemic disparities and injustices in a particular area, propose a path of action and present your pitch in a concise and persuasive manner.

Please see Blackboard for details of the task, including the scenario, submission requirements, and uploading instructions, as well as the marking criteria that will be used to assess your work.

Note: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction: Welcome & What is Social Inequality?

Welcome to week 1 of SOCY1070 which serves as an introduction to the course. There is a learning module for Week 1 to help you get oriented to the course and to provide you with links to some helpful resources and support. You are expected to come to class having read the Course Profile and the Course Study Guide. 

Building on what you have learned from the Study Guide for the course, in this week’s workshop we look at how learning will happen in the course, what you need to do to pass the course, and the resources that will assist you. You will be invited to reflect on your personal connections to the topic of inequality through a critical incident timeline. We will then introduce two key theories that underpin this course.

learning_activities.topic:
Why does social inequality matter?

Welcome to Week 2 of SOCY1070 where we look more closely at why social inequality matters, and why, as social scientists we might be interested in it. Our online modules introduce this topic with interviews, videos and readings. In the workshop we build on these to deepen discussion and think about the role our own values play in how we approach social inequality.

In the second part of our workshop, we engage in Assessment 1 for the course. This is the first of four such in-class exercises. This week’s work is an opportunity to practice the assessment style, without the pressure of marks - as it will not be graded. It will give you an opportunity to understand how assessment will work and to ensure you can submit your work successfully in the weeks to come. You can see further details about Assessment 1 in the course Study Guide.

learning_activities.topic:
How do we know if/where social inequality exists?

Measurement is one means by which we can recognise the existence of inequality, and understand whether it is changing – for better or worse. However, this is not a neutral, straightforward process. In this week’s learning module, Associate Professor “Paco” Perales takes us through the terrain of measuring inequality, via a series of video lectures. 

Please note that as Monday of this week is a public holiday in Queensland, there are no face-to-face workshops this week, only the online module for you to complete.

Please reach out to your tutors should you need clarity about any of the module material.

learning_activities.topic:
What causes social inequality?

Our focus this week is on the causes of social inequality. Through the online learning module, we begin with the idea of othering, and essentialising the other. We also distinguish between social categorisation and social devaluation and look at how judgement cycles are formed at the individual and social levels and explore the important topic of “unconscious bias”. 

Our workshop engages with the often uncomfortable topic of “othering” and the process of social devaluation. Please come to class having engaged with the online module, and a somewhat unusual reading, to prepare you for our case study on modern slavery.

learning_activities.topic:
Is social inequality inevitable?

In this week’s online learning module we ask, “Is social inequality inevitable?” by thinking about the history of inequality and how it has manifested over time. We will also ask the question, “So, are things getting better or worse?” and consider whether we are getting closer to equality for all. You might be surprised at the answer.

In the first half of today’s workshop we invite you to apply your learning from the module to begin Assessment 2. Assessment 2 is due in the final week of semester but will require ongoing work throughout the semester and our aim is to help you get started early.

In the second half of the workshop we will undertake Assessment item 1(b). Assessment 1 is a series of 4 in-class writing exercises and today’s exercise will be the first graded component, worth 20% of your final mark. If you cannot make your workshop time, please see the Study Guide for options for how you can still complete this assessment item. Assessment 1(b) will focus on material from any of the previous weeks (Weeks 2-4).

learning_activities.topic:
Inequality and the impact of colonisation

Last week we took a broad historical lens to the idea of social inequality. This week we narrow our focus to the specific topic of colonialisation and the impact of colonisation on First nations people. We do this by engaging with the excellent online resources “History lives in us”. This work examines how events and policies in the past have shaped the identities and experiences of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples today. The Module looks at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander activism; the ‘rights’ movement and campaigns waged by key organisations in the lead up to the establishment of the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs in 1972. This week’s workshop invites further engagement with the module and examines in what ways this history is still powerfully with us and the consequences for first nations people globally and in Australia.

learning_activities.topic:
Theories of inequality - Intersectionality and Privilege

Often, sociology courses and texts on inequality provide a weekly run-down on different axes of inequality: gender in Week 1, race in Week 2, class in Week 3, and so on. In this course, we have deliberately chosen not to do that, but to instead foreground intersectional understandings of inequality. This week's learning module focuses on this idea by introducing the topics of positionality, privilege, intersectionality and compound disadvantage. We will continue this discussion in our workshop where we will invite you to think about your own connections to privilege and intersectionality with a series of in-class exercises. As self-identified black, lesbian, feminist, mother, poet, warrior, and cancer-survivor, Audre Lorde (1984) says, “There is no such thing as a single-issue struggle because we do not live single-issue lives.”

learning_activities.topic:
Theories of inequality - Power/Knowledge

For those of you who have previously studied sociology, you were likely introduced to some of key thinkers in sociological theory: Marx, Weber, Durkheim, for example. In this course we reference these important thinkers, but we want to bring in a different theoretical perspective by thinking about the work of Michel Foucault and how his ideas of power/knowledge and discipline have shaped our thinking in new and exciting ways and given us new understandings of the dynamics of inequality. In the first half of this week’s workshop, we will apply Foucault’s thinking about power/knowledge, introduced in the learning module, and use a jigsaw reading exercise to help us work through some of these more complex ideas. In the second half of the workshop, we will undertake Assessment item 1(c), the third in a series of 4 in-class writing exercises. Today’s in-class assessment is worth 20% of your final mark. If you cannot make your workshop time, please see the Study Guide for options on how you can still complete this assessment item. Assessment 1(c) will focus on material from any of the previous weeks (Weeks 5-7).

learning_activities.topic:
Social inequality - Is change possible?

Week 9 focuses on the evolution of inequality over time, examining individual fluctuations and life course perspectives. Associate Professor Paco Perales's recorded lecture poses the question: does being born poor mean staying poor? We will also delve into intergenerational transmission of advantage/disadvantage, exploring broader societal impacts. Transitioning from micro to macro analysis, we'll scrutinise the role of social institutions in shaping equal or unequal societies. Completing the online Learning Module before the seminar is essential for productive class discussions.

learning_activities.topic:
Responding to social Inequality – Solution focused social science

So far we have spent the semester exploring social inequality – what it is, why it exists, how it can be measured, and its various often devastating impacts. For the last few weeks of semester we are looking at how we might respond, which links to the idea of “Solution focused social science”. Our learning module this week introduces this idea, suggesting that the role of social science is not simply to study phenomena, but to provide solutions towards resolving modern social challenges. 

As Wednesday of this week is a public holiday in Brisbane there are no workshops scheduled. However, we will be monitoring online communications should you have any queries about the online materials.

learning_activities.topic:
What strategies can we use for social transformation?

Throughout this course we have highlighted the central concepts of agency and structure. We have spent the last section of the course looking at how structure operates. Now we flip to thinking about agency – first of all, how we exercise individual agency, as well as the limits of our individual agency. Then we begin thinking about collective agency, how we can work deliberately to create change in social structures. In the first half of this week’s class, we apply the ideas of individual and collective agency to the case study of fast fashion. How could we create change in this global human rights and environmental challenge? This will help you in your thinking about the final assessment piece for the course. In the second half of the workshop we will undertake Assessment item 1(d), the third in a series of 4 in-class writing exercises. Today’s in-class assessment is worth 20% of your final mark. If you cannot make your workshop time, please see the Study Guide for options on how you can still complete this assessment item. Assessment 1(d) will focus on material from any of the previous weeks (Weeks 8-10).
